awd_titl_txt: EarthCube IA: Advancing netCDF-CF  for the Geoscience Community
awd_abstract_narration:
For a collection of scientific data to be useful to multiple independent research groups, the collection must contain auxiliary information that describes where and how the data were collected, the units of measurement used, and other similar details. This auxiliary information, known as "metadata," is crucial to allowing scientists to understand the physical and derived quantities captured by the data.  The Climate and Forecast (CF) metadata conventions for netCDF (netCDF-CF)  are currently used widely by weather forecasters, climate scientists, and remote-sensing researchers to include metadata along with scientific data, and numerous open source and commercial software tools have been developed to explore and analyze data sets that use the conventions. This project will work to extend the existing metadata conventions in ways that will broaden the range of  earth science domains whose data can be represented.  By broadening the applicability of an established convention, this effort seeks to extend its benefits to related earth science domains and reduce the amount of effort scientists must expend decoding and reformatting datasets created by other research groups. This, in turn, will leave researchers more time for analysis, leading to a better understanding of the physical processes the data describe.

NetCDF-CF is a community-developed standard first released in 2003. Originally designed to represent climate and forecast model output encoded in the netCDF binary format, with the specific goal of facilitating comparison of output from different models, the standard is now widely accepted in the climate, weather, and remote-sensing research communities, but less so in other earth science domains. This project will extend the standard to better represent a data set's spatial extents, and to encompass earth science data sets not currently covered by the conventions, including radar and more complex satellite data. Additionally, the project will work to make netCDF-CF compatible with data stored in modern data structures developed since the original creation of the conventions. Since netCDF-CF is a community-based standard, the approach will be to bring stakeholders from the existing CF community together with experts from domains into which CF can logically be extended so they can work together to design and prototype a series of enhancements, which will be submitted to the larger community for consideration. The envisioned improvements will help diverse research groups use the conventions to faithfully represent their data in formats accessible using standard, widely-available software tools.  This type of cross-domain data interoperability has the potential to give rise to more effective, integrated decisionmaking tools for a wide range of communities.

por.por_cntn:
For a collection of scientific data to be useful to multiple independent research groups, the collection must contain auxiliary information that describes where and how the data were collected, the units of measurement used, and other similar details. This auxiliary information, or "metadata," is crucial to allowing scientists to understand the meaning of the data. This project worked to extend the Climate and Forecast (CF) metadata conventions for netCDF (netCDF-CF) in ways that would broaden the types of Earth system science data that can be stored in netCDF-CF data files; it also worked to engage scientists from Earth system science domains that have not traditionally used netCDF-CF. 

This project helped develop and propose a number of extensions to the CF Convention including the following. The CF Geometries extension gives users a standard way to represent segments of a river network or a set of catchment basins (or other features that can be represented by lines and polygons) in a netCDF-CF dataset. The CF Groups extension spells out how best to use netCDF Groups to store data in a hierarchical structure. The CF Satellite Swath proposed extension describes the netCDF-CF structures used to represent the complex data often found in satellite swath data (e.g., the field-of-view of scanning multi-sensor instruments).

To encourage participation by a broad range of Earth system science domains, a variety of outreach and engagement activities were undertaken. Updates on netCDF-CF activities were presented regularly at conferences and workshops, conference sessions and side meetings were also held for more detailed discussions of netCDF-­CF. Annual community workshops for netCDF-CF were held each year of the project with attendees from academia, government agencies, and the private sector representing a variety of Earth system science domains.

The project’s work on extensions for the netCDF-CF standard has expanded the types of data that can be encoded with netCDF-CF. Support for these extensions in key software libraries and tools has improved access and use of these new data types. Along with allowing current netCDF-CF users to encode new types of data, the new extensions, prototype implementations, and outreach have allowed and encouraged netCDF-CF use by many Earth System Science domains that have not traditionally used netCDF-CF. For instance, use of netCDF-CF has expanded into Hydrology and Ocean observing communities.
